Subject: Re: [junit] use of setUp and tearDown
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=12653864; y=-hdhKC9yhAWorQwzJg1EUfmbaJEV5HiA-xL6veM-5A0EFl9O

Cedric Beust wrote:

> Your suggestion doesn't scale for teams bigger than just yourself...
> 

All that's needed is for people to run the tests before checking 
anything in. Don't break the build. Team size really doesn't enter into 
it. To some extent this is cultural. if the team culture allows people 
to check in code that breaks previously working tests, then yes. 
Debugging will, be tougher, though I fail to see how distinguishing 
between skipped and errored tests will help. Indeed, sometimes it's not 
even the first failed test that makes the problem the most obvious. The 
more failed tests you have the more and better the opportunities for 
debugging. If one failed test does not have an obvious cause, then try 
the next one. You're just throwing away potentially useful information 
by offering only one failure.

Furthermore, in a team larger than one, I find it even more unlikely 
that anyone can untangle the web of dependencies accurately enough to 
figure out what tests depend on the functionality tested by which other 
tests.

-- 
Elliotte Rusty Harold  elharo@...

subject: Re: [junit] use of setUp and tearDown
